questions.text: Which of the following conditions follows the inheritance pattern shown in the given pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given pedigree chart shows mitochondrial inheritance, and among the given options, Kearns-Sayre syndrome follows this pattern of inheritance.

  • Each mitochondrion contains multiple copies of its own circular chromosome that encodes tRNAs, rRNAs, and proteins essential for oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Because sperm contribute negligible cytoplasmic components to the zygote, mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively through the maternal line.
  • All children of affected mothers inherit the disorder, while affected fathers do not transmit it to their offspring.
  • Mutations in mitochondrial DNA impair oxidative phosphorylation, reducing ATP production, generating free radicals, and triggering apoptosis, affecting high-energy-demand tissues such as skeletal muscle, heart, and neurons.
  • Skeletal muscle involvement may present as weakness, elevated creatine kinase, or rhabdomyolysis, often with extraocular muscle weakness such as chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia.
  • Pathologically, muscle fibres may show subsarcolemmal aggregates of abnormal mitochondria in the form of ragged red fibres, as shown below or loss of specific mitochondrial enzyme activities.
  • A key feature of mitochondrial disorders is heteroplasmy: While mitochondrial DNA replicates independently of nuclear DNA, different cells and tissues can carry varying proportions of mutant and wild-type mitochondria, leading to wide variation in when and how disease manifests.
  • Single mutations can cause mild isolated symptoms in one person and severe multisystem disease, such as mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) in another.
  • They can result from point mutations or deletions in mitochondrial DNA, as in Kearns-Sayre syndrome, myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibres, or Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, and may also arise from nuclear gene mutations affecting mitochondrial proteins.

Explanation of other options:

Achondroplasia (Option A): Achondroplasia follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Autosomal dominant disorders occur when the mutation is present in a single allele, so at least one parent of the affected individual is usually affected, and the condition can be transmitted by either sex.

Williams syndrome (Option C): Typically arises from a 7q11.23 deletion and is marked by supravalvular aortic stenosis, hypercalcemia, and orofacial features.

Prader-Willi syndrome (Option D): Prader-Willi syndrome arises due to genomic imprinting. Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where certain genes are expressed in a parent-of-origin-specific manner, meaning one parental allele (maternal or paternal) is selectively inactivated through mechanisms like DNA methylation and histone modification.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of disseminated gonococcal infection. A joint aspirate during an episode of joint pain reveals Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following could be the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Terminal complement deficiency predisposes to disseminated neisserial infections.

  • A major genetic risk factor for neisserial infections is deficiency of the terminal complement components (C5-C9), as well as properdin or factor D, which can increase susceptibility by up to 600-fold and lead to recurrent disease, since these components are crucial for the bactericidal activity of serum.
  • The complement system is a set of over 20 plasma proteins, named C1 through C9, among others, that play a central role in innate and adaptive immunity by defending against microbes and participating in inflammatory responses.
  • These proteins circulate in an inactive form and, upon activation through one of three pathways, classical, alternative, or lectin, trigger an enzymatic cascade that amplifies immune defence as shown below.
  • All pathways converge at the activation of C3, producing fragments C3a and C3b.
  • C3b facilitates opsonisation, while downstream activation leads to C5b binding and assembly of the membrane attack complex (C6-C9), which lyses targeted cells.
  • Complement functions include promoting inflammation, enhancing phagocytosis, and directly lysing pathogens, particularly those with thin cell walls such as Neisseria species.
  • Deficiencies in terminal components of complement increase susceptibility to Neisseria infections, while regulatory proteins like C1 inhibitor, DAF, CD59, and complement factor H control activation to prevent host tissue damage.
  • Inherited or acquired defects in these proteins can lead to increased infection risk or conditions associated with excessive complement activation.
  • Complement deficiencies can affect virtually all components of the complement system and its regulators, and may be hereditary or acquired. The most frequent is C2 deficiency, followed by C4 or C1q deficiencies, which impair the classical pathway and are linked to increased bacterial or viral infections, though many remain asymptomatic due to compensation by the alternative pathway. These deficiencies can sometimes manifest as SLE-like autoimmune disease.
  • C3 deficiency, critical for both classical and alternative pathways, leads to severe, recurrent bacterial infections and immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis due to impaired immune complex clearance.
  • Deficiency of C1 inhibitor causes hereditary angioedema, characterised by episodic swelling of skin, mucosa, and internal tissues due to unregulated kallikrein activation and bradykinin production, sometimes leading to life-threatening airway or gastrointestinal involvement. (Option D ruled out)
  • Other regulatory protein deficiencies contribute to disorders such as paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, hemolytic uremic syndrome, and age-related macular degeneration.

Explanation of other options:

Myeloperoxidase deficiency (Option A): Myeloperoxidase (MPO) deficiency is the most frequent neutrophil defect, inherited as an autosomal recessive condition. Individuals with both MPO deficiency and diabetes are more prone to Candida infections. An acquired form of MPO deficiency may develop in conditions such as myelomonocytic leukaemia and acute myeloid leukaemia.

PMN cell chemotactic defect (Option B): Leukocyte adhesion defects are inherited disorders that impair the ability of white blood cells to adhere to the endothelium, hindering their migration into tissues and predisposing patients to recurrent, often severe, bacterial infections.

questions.text: A patient presents with long limbs and ectopia lentis. His arm span is found to be greater than his height. Marfan syndrome is suspected. Which of the following gene defects is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A fibrillin gene defect is responsible for Marfan syndrome.

  • Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that primarily affects the skeleton, eyes, and cardiovascular system.
  • Around 70-85% of cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to mutations in the FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1, while the rest arise from new mutations.
  • Fibrillin-1 is a key component of microfibrils in the extracellular matrix, providing structural support in areas such as the aorta, ligaments, and lens zonules.
  • Defective fibrillin disrupts microfibril formation and reduces sequestration of TGF-β, leading to its excessive activation. This overactive TGF-β signalling contributes to inflammation, abnormal tissue remodelling, and connective tissue weakness.
  • Mutations are mostly missense types, causing either abnormal fibrillin polymerisation or reduced fibrillin levels.
  • Related conditions include congenital contractural arachnodactyly from FBN2 mutations and Marfan-like syndromes from TGF-β receptor or ligand mutations.
  • Clinically, skeletal changes are the most noticeable feature: patients are often tall with long limbs, fingers, and toes. They tend to have hyperextensible joints, dolichocephaly, and chest deformities such as pectus excavatum or carinatum.
  • Ocular involvement includes bilateral lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) from weak ciliary zonules. Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most life-threatening, especially aortic root dilation, cystic medial necrosis, aortic regurgitation, and dissection, as well as mitral valve prolapse and regurgitation. These cardiovascular complications are the leading cause of mortality, often due to rupture of aortic dissections.
  • Diagnosis uses the revised Ghent criteria, incorporating family history, key clinical signs, and evidence of FBN1 mutations.

Explanation of other options:

A) PLOD1 (Option A): PLOD1 gene encodes lysyl hydroxylase, and a mutation in this gene results in kyphoscoliosis type (type VI) of Ehler-Danlos syndrome.

B) Elastin (Option B): Elastin defects are associated with cutis laxa and Williams syndrome.

D) COL1A1 (Option D): COL1A1 and COL1A2 gene defects lead to arthrochalasia type (type VIIa and VIIb) of Ehler-Danlos syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a 2-year history of progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and ataxia. An MRI imaging of the brain reveals a well-defined tumour located in the cerebellopontine angle (CPA). A surgical resection is performed, and subsequent histopathological examination of the tumour reveals Antoni A and B areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of a patient with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, ataxia, with imaging revealing cerebellopontine angle tumour and histopathological findings of Antoni A and B areas is consistent with a diagnosis of schwannoma.

  • Schwannomas are benign tumours usually originating from peripheral nerves. They are linked to inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22, with loss of the NF2 gene product, merlin, seen in all cases.
  • Morphologically, schwannomas are encapsulated, well-defined masses loosely attached to nerves, allowing removal without loss of nerve function.
  • Grossly, they are firm and grey, composed of alternating dense (Antoni A) and loose (Antoni B) areas as shown below.
  • Antoni A areas have eosinophilic spindle cells in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading, forming structures called Verocay bodies.
  • Antoni B areas have sparse cells in a myxoid extracellular matrix, sometimes with microcysts.
  • These tumours show S-100 immunoreactivity and may undergo degenerative changes such as nuclear pleomorphism, xanthomatous change, vascular hyalinization, cystic change, and necrosis.
  • Clinically, they produce symptoms from compression of nerves or nearby structures. Intracranially, they often occur at the cerebellopontine angle on the vestibular branch of the eighth nerve, causing tinnitus and hearing loss and are commonly termed acoustic neuroma, though this name is misleading.
  • They can also affect the trigeminal branches, dorsal roots, or present as extradural masses on large nerves or soft tissue without nerve association. Surgical excision is curative.

Explanation of other options:

Meningioma (Option A): Meningiomas are typically slow-growing tumours that may cause vague, nonlocalizing symptoms or focal neurological deficits. Hormonal influence,s such as progesterone receptors, may lead to accelerated growth during pregnancy. Histologically, meningiomas present in various patterns such as meningothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, and psammomatous. The following image shows numerous psammoma bodies in a meningioma specimen.

On imaging, a common feature is the dural tail, which appears as a thickened, enhancing extension of the dura projecting from the main lesion.

Ependymoma (Option B): Ependymomas in the posterior fossa commonly present with hydrocephalus due to progressive blockage of the fourth ventricle, while CSF dissemination is uncommon. Histologically, they consist of cells with fibrillary processes and round to oval nuclei, often forming ependymal canals or perivascular pseudorosettes, as shown below.

Vestibular neuritis (Option D): Vestibular neuritis presents with sudden, persistent vertigo accompanied by nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia, and imbalance due to asymmetric vestibular input, with symptoms continuing even when the head is still.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with cervical lymph node enlargement and increased bleeding tendency. Bone marrow examination reveals >25% blasts, and the peripheral smear is as shown below. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given features of cervical lymphadenopathy and bleeding tendency alongside bone marrow with >25% blasts and auer rods on peripheral smear is suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukaemia, which is associated with t(15;17).

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a malignant disorder of hematopoietic progenitor cells caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that disrupt differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.
  • This accumulation replaces normal marrow elements, resulting in marrow failure and clinical consequences such as anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.
  • AML can occur at any age but is more common in older adults, with incidence increasing significantly after age 60.
  • Pathogenesis involves several classes of mutations. The chromosomal abnormalities t(8;21) and inv(16) are the most frequent rearrangements, disrupting the RUNX1 and CBFB genes, respectively.
  • The rearrangements generate chimeric genes that code for fusion proteins, which impair RUNX1/CBFB function and block the maturation of myeloid cells.
  • In acute promyelocytic leukaemia, a t(15;17) translocation creates a PML-RARα fusion protein that arrests granulocyte differentiation, treatable with all-trans retinoic acid and arsenic trioxide.
  • Diagnosis requires at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, identified morphologically by delicate chromatin, two to four nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm.
  • Auer rods are distinctive needle-like inclusions often seen in AML, especially with t(15;17). (Options A and C ruled out)
  • Immunophenotyping confirms the diagnosis by detecting myeloid-specific antigens.
  • In AML, clinical features usually develop over weeks to months and are due to marrow failure from blast replacement.
  • Patients often present with fatigue from anaemia, spontaneous mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal haemorrhages from thrombocytopenia, and recurrent or severe infections from neutropenia.
  • Fever is common, and bleeding may be pronounced in cases with t(15;17) due to the release of procoagulants.
  • Some patients develop extramedullary involvement such as gingival hypertrophy, skin infiltration (leukaemia cutis), or localised soft tissue masses (myeloid sarcoma).

Explanation of other options:

t(9;22) (Option D): In chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) and certain cases of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, the ABL gene relocates from its usual position on chromosome 9 to chromosome 22, where it merges with the BCR gene. This translocation produces a fusion gene that encodes the BCR-ABL chimeric protein, which possesses continuous tyrosine kinase activity.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with progressive, painless testicular swelling. Gross examination of the testis shows a multinodular, homogeneous, gray-white mass without haemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological examination is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given features of painless testicular swelling with gross examination revealing a homogeneous mass and histopathology revealing lymphocytic fibrous cords separating poorly defined lobules of cells is seminoma.

  • Seminoma is the most frequent type of germ cell tumour (GCT), representing about half of all cases, with peak occurrence in the fourth decade.
  • These tumours typically form large masses, sometimes reaching up to ten times the normal testis size, with a homogeneous, gray-white, lobulated surface that usually lacks haemorrhage or necrosis.
  • The tunica albuginea is generally intact, though spread to the epididymis, spermatic cord, or scrotal sac may occur.
  • Histologically, seminomas are composed of sheets of uniform cells separated into lobules by fine fibrous septa with lymphocytic infiltration, and some may have ill-defined granulomas as part of a host response.
  • Classic seminoma cells are round to polyhedral, with a distinct membrane, clear or watery cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus containing one or two prominent nucleoli, often with glycogen deposits.
  • Immunohistochemically, tumour cells are usually KIT and OCT3/4 positive, podoplanin positive, and cytokeratin negative. Around 15% contain syncytiotrophoblasts, leading to elevated serum hCG levels, though generally less than in choriocarcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Yolk sac tumour (Option A): Yolk sac tumour, also called endodermal sinus tumour, is the most common testicular tumour in infants and children under 3 years old. Microscopically, these tumours typically display a lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells with less cytologic atypia compared to embryonal carcinoma. About half of the cases show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are structures resembling primitive glomeruli with a mesodermal core, central capillary, and visceral and parietal cell layers as shown below.

Embryonal carcinoma (Option C): Embryonal carcinomas are locally aggressive tumours that often invade through the tunica albuginea into the epididymis or spermatic cord. On gross examination, they present a variegated appearance due to areas of haemorrhage or necrosis. Microscopically, the tumour cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes forming papillary folds, while undifferentiated areas may consist of sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The cells are large, anaplastic, with hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, indistinct cell borders, and marked pleomorphism.

Leydig cell tumour (Option D): Leydig cell tumours are well-circumscribed nodules, typically less than 5 cm in diameter, with a distinctive golden-brown, homogeneous cut surface. Microscopically, the tumour cells resemble normal Leydig cells, being large with round or polygonal outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a central round nucleus. The cytoplasm often contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment, and some tumours display characteristic rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids shown below.

questions.text: A patient presents with a midline neck swelling. Histology showed amyloid deposition, and immunohistochemistry is positive for synaptophysin, chromogranin, and TTF-1. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the features of histopathological examination showing amyloid deposition in a midline neck swelling and immunohistochemistry revealing synaptophysin, chromogranin, and TTF-1 positivity, the most likely diagnosis is medullary thyroid cancer.

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a neuroendocrine tumour derived from parafollicular C cells.
  • These tumours secrete calcitonin, which is important for diagnosis and follow-up, and can also produce other hormones like serotonin, ACTH, and VIP.
  • Most are sporadic, while the rest are associated with MEN-2A or MEN-2B syndromes due to activating RET proto-oncogene mutations.
  • MEN-associated cases occur in younger patients, sometimes in the first decade, whereas sporadic cases typically appear in adulthood, peaking in the 40s and 50s.
  • Sporadic tumours usually present as solitary nodules, while familial cases often show bilaterality and multicentricity.
  • Grossly, they are firm, pale grey to tan, and infiltrative, sometimes with necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • Microscopically, they are composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells arranged in nests, trabeculae, or follicles, with anaplastic cells in some tumours.
  • Amyloid deposits from calcitonin peptides are common, and calcitonin can be demonstrated in both the cytoplasm and stromal amyloid, as shown below.
  • Ultrastructurally, they contain membrane-bound electron-dense granules typical of neuroendocrine tumours, and immunohistochemical testing shows positivity for markers of endocrine granules, including synaptophysin and chromogranin A.
  • Nuclear staining for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1) is commonly observed in cancers of the lung and thyroid.

Explanation of other options:

Papillary thyroid cancer (Option A): Papillary thyroid carcinoma may have ill-defined margins and can involve adjacent parenchyma, sometimes with areas of fibrosis, calcification, or cystic change. The cut surface may display papillary foci. Papillary microcarcinoma refers to lesions under 1 cm but otherwise identical histologically. Microscopically, they show branching papillae with fibrovascular cores lined by cuboidal epithelial cells, varying from uniform to markedly anaplastic. Nuclei characteristically have finely dispersed chromatin and a clear, empty appearance known as ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are shown below, with possible nuclear grooves or pseudoinclusions. Psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures, are often present within papillary cores, strongly indicating papillary carcinoma.

Follicular thyroid cancer (Option C): Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid usually appears as a single nodule, which may be either well-circumscribed or widely infiltrative. Microscopically, most tumours consist of uniform cells forming small follicles with colloid, as shown below, resembling normal thyroid, though some have less apparent follicular differentiation with nests or sheets of cells lacking colloid. In some cases, cells contain abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, known as the Hürthle cell or oncocytic variant. Thyroglobulin is commonly used to monitor recurrence.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer (Option D): Poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas consist of cells with minimal follicular differentiation, arranged in insular or trabecular patterns, often with intratumoral necrosis and frequent mitoses. Anaplastic carcinomas show variable morphology, including large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells with a sarcomatoid appearance, or a mix of both, and may retain foci of papillary or follicular differentiation, indicating origin from a well-differentiated carcinoma. These tumours express epithelial markers like cytokeratin but are typically negative for thyroid differentiation markers such as thyroglobulin.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the liver shows a well-circumscribed lesion, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross specimen of liver showing a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar points to a diagnosis of focal nodular hyperplasia.

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign, non-neoplastic liver lesion most frequently seen in adult women.
  • It is believed to result from altered hepatic blood flow, which induces hyperplastic changes in hepatocytes.
  • These nodules may arise near other tumours or in association with vascular disorders such as hemangiomas and Budd–Chiari syndrome, and multifocal FNH can be linked to hepatic or extrahepatic hemangiomas, vascular malformations, or even certain brain tumours like meningioma and astrocytoma.
  • Morphologically, FNH is well-circumscribed, lacks a capsule, and commonly exhibits a central stellate scar in up to 80% of cases.
  • Lesions are usually 5 cm or smaller, with fibrous septa radiating from the central scar, dividing the liver parenchyma into nodules.
  • The scar and septa contain thick-walled arteries with intimal and fibromuscular hyperplasia and poorly developed elastic lamina.
  • A ductular reaction is frequently present, though interlobular bile ducts are absent.
  • Hepatocytes are arranged in one- to two-cell-thick plates without cytologic or architectural atypia.
  • Immunohistochemistry for glutamine synthetase (GS) shows a distinctive maplike pattern of strong cytoplasmic staining in anastomosing hepatocyte groups.
  • Clinically, most cases are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery. The presence of a central scar is a key imaging clue for diagnosis.
  • MRI provides the most accurate diagnosis, achieving 100% specificity when classic features are observed, namely homogeneous arterial phase enhancement accompanied by a central scar as shown below.
  • FNH does not require treatment, although resection may be performed for large or symptomatic lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatocellular adenoma (Option A): Hepatocellular adenomas present as well-defined masses, as shown below, sometimes accompanied by haemorrhage, and are composed of hepatocytes arranged in plates that are one to two cells thick.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option B): Hepatocellular carcinoma can present as a solitary mass, multiple distinct nodules, or as a diffuse infiltrative growth throughout the liver. The tumours may appear pale yellow from fatty change or green from cholestasis. Lesions exceeding 2 cm in size are more frequently linked to vascular invasion and intrahepatic spread. In some cases, venous invasion can extend into the portal vein, inferior vena cava, and even the right atrium of the heart.

Regenerative nodule (Option D): In chronic liver disease, the remaining hepatocytes attempt to regenerate the damaged parenchyma, resulting in the formation of regenerative nodules, which are a hallmark finding in most cirrhotic livers.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with bilateral cervical lymph node enlargement. Histopathological examination reveals small cleaved cells as well as larger cells with open chromatin. Immunohistochemistry reveals CD10-positive and BCL2-positive cells. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An elderly patient presenting with cervical lymphadenopathy along with both small cleaved cells and larger cells, which are CD10 and BCL2 positive, points to a diagnosis of follicular lymphoma, which is associated with t(14;18).

  • Follicular lymphoma is the most common type of indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma, typically in middle age, with equal prevalence in males and females.
  • It is strongly linked to chromosomal translocations involving BCL2, most notably the t(14;18) translocation in about 90% of cases, which leads to BCL2 overexpression and inhibition of apoptosis.
  • Morphologically, the lymph nodes show a nodular or mixed nodular-diffuse growth pattern.
  • Two main cell types are present: small cleaved cells (centrocytes) with irregular nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, and larger cells (centroblasts) with open chromatin, nucleoli, and moderate cytoplasm. Centrocytes predominate in most cases.
  • The histopathological findings are shown in the image below.
  • Bone marrow involvement is seen in 85% of cases, typically as paratrabecular lymphoid aggregates, with frequent splenic white pulp and hepatic portal triad infiltration.
  • The immunophenotype closely resembles germinal centre B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface immunoglobulin, and BCL6, but lacking CD5.
  • BCL2 is expressed in over 90% of cases, unlike normal germinal centre B cells, which are BCL2-negative.
  • Clinically, patients often present with painless, generalised lymphadenopathy. Extranodal involvement is uncommon, and the disease usually has a slow, waxing and waning course.

Explanation of other options:

t(11;18) (Option A): Extranodal marginal zone lymphomas (MALTomas) can harbour chromosomal rearrangements, including the t(11;18) translocation, which is relatively characteristic for this subtype and leads to upregulation of signalling proteins that enhance B-cell growth and survival. It causes increased production and activity of BCL10 or MALT1, which are key components of a signalling complex that triggers NF-κB activation, thereby enhancing B-cell proliferation and survival.

t(11;14) (Option C): Mantle cell lymphoma is characterised by the t(11;14) translocation leading to cyclin D1 overexpression and driving progression from the G to S phase of the cell cycle. Microscopically, the tumour typically shows a uniform population of small lymphocytes with irregular to cleaved nuclear contours, condensed chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm, lacking large centroblast-like cells and proliferation centres. Immunophenotypically, the neoplastic cells express high levels of cyclin D1, CD19, and CD20, along with surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chains), and are CD5 positive but CD23 negative.

t(8;14) (Option D): The commonest translocation seen in Burkitt’s lymphoma is t(8;14), but t(2;8) and t(8;22) are also seen. Burkitt lymphoma is characterised by a diffuse infiltration of medium-sized lymphoid cells and shows a high mitotic rate with numerous apoptotic cells, whose nuclear debris is engulfed by macrophages, producing the classic starry sky appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following are caspase-mediated forms of cell death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apoptosis and pyroptosis are caspase-mediated processes, which makes Option C the correct answer.

  • Cell death primarily occurs through two mechanisms: necrosis and apoptosis, which differ in their triggers, molecular pathways, morphology, and physiological or pathological roles.
  • Apoptosis is a regulated, energy-dependent process in which cells destined to die activate internal enzymes known as caspases that degrade nuclear DNA and cytoplasmic proteins.
  • Cells shrink, form membrane-bound fragments called apoptotic bodies, and are cleared by phagocytes without triggering inflammation.
  • Necrosis is typically an accidental form of cell death caused by irreversible damage to essential cellular structures. It is linked to conditions such as ischemia, toxin exposure, infections, and trauma. It is not a caspase-mediated process. (Option B ruled out)
  • The process involves denaturation of proteins, loss of membrane integrity, and enzymatic digestion of cellular components, resulting in leakage of intracellular contents and inflammation.
  • The distinguishing features between apoptosis and necrosis are summarised in the table given below.

Other less common forms of cell death include necroptosis, pyroptosis, and ferroptosis.

  • Necroptosis is a hybrid process sharing features of both necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it involves loss of ATP, swelling of organelles, ROS generation, lysosomal enzyme release, and plasma membrane rupture, but it is triggered by programmed signalling pathways similar to apoptosis.
  • It is caspase-independent and often initiated through TNFR1 activation, leading to RIPK1-RIPK3-MLKL signalling, MLKL phosphorylation, and membrane disruption. It plays roles in both physiological processes (e.g., bone growth plate formation) and pathological conditions (e.g., steatohepatitis, pancreatitis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative diseases). (Option A ruled out)
  • Pyroptosis is a cell death pathway linked to infection and inflammation, triggered when intracellular receptors detect microbial products and activate the inflammasome. This leads to caspase-1 activation, cleavage of IL-1 precursors, and release of IL-1, promoting inflammation and fever. It also results in cell death through caspase-4 and -5 activation.
  • Ferroptosis is caused by excessive iron-dependent lipid peroxidation when antioxidant defences fail. It leads to membrane damage and cell death, with ultrastructural changes including reduced mitochondrial cristae and rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane. While its physiological role is debated, it has been linked to cancer, neurodegeneration, and stroke. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presents with mild anaemia and jaundice. Examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory findings show an elevated mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC). His father has also had a similar clinical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on anaemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and similar history in consequent generations is suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited red blood cell disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the membrane skeleton, making red cells spheroidal, less deformable, and prone to splenic sequestration and destruction.
  • It has an autosomal dominant inheritance in roughly 75% of cases. The normal deformability of red cells is due to a specialised membrane skeleton, mainly composed of spectrin, which connects to the membrane via interactions involving ankyrin, band 4.2, band 3, and protein 4.1 with glycophorin A.
  • Mutations in these proteins impair membrane stability, leading to membrane loss, reduced surface-to-volume ratio, and the spheroidal shape.
  • This structural abnormality decreases red cell lifespan from the normal 120 days to about 10-20 days.
  • Morphologically, blood smears show small, dense, hyperchromic red cells lacking central pallor, as shown below, with splenic trapping causing extravascular hemolysis.
  • The spleen's filtering role exacerbates red cell destruction, and changes in pH, ion balance, and glucose metabolism further contribute.
  • Clinical features include anaemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice, with severity ranging from asymptomatic to severe neonatal anaemia.
  • Many patients have increased osmotic fragility and elevated mean cell haemoglobin concentration. About 40-50% develop pigment gallstones.
  • The course may be complicated by aplastic crises, often due to parvovirus B19 infection or hemolytic crises during intercurrent illnesses.
  • Splenectomy corrects the anaemia but leaves spherocytes in circulation and increases susceptibility to certain infections.

Explanation of other options:

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option B): In iron deficiency anaemia, bone marrow shows mild to moderate erythroid hyperplasia with the absence of stainable iron in macrophages. Peripheral blood smears reveal microcytic, hypochromic red cells with enlarged central pallor, pencil-shaped cells, and poikilocytosis as shown below.

Clinically, patients may present with symptoms linked to the underlying cause, along with pallor, fatigue, pica, koilonychia, and alopecia. Laboratory findings include low haemoglobin, hematocrit, serum iron, and ferritin with increased total iron-binding capacity.

Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (Option C): Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (AIHA) occurs when antibodies target red blood cells, leading to their early destruction. It is classified into warm antibody type (IgG active at 37°C), cold agglutinin type (IgM active at low temperatures), and cold hemolysin type (IgG causing paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria), each with distinct triggers, mechanisms, and clinical features. Diagnosis relies on Coombs testing, and management depends on removing triggers, immunosuppression, splenectomy, or avoiding cold exposure, depending on the subtype. The given scenario is more consistent with hereditary spherocytosis.

Thalassemia minor (Option D): β-thalassemia minor is a heterozygous condition (β°/β or β+/β) that is generally asymptomatic or associated with mild anaemia. Peripheral smears show microcytosis, hypochromia, basophilic stippling, and target cells, while bone marrow may exhibit mild erythroid hyperplasia. Haemoglobin electrophoresis typically reveals increased HbA(4-8%) and normal or slightly raised HbF.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with progressive vision loss, and an MRI was done, which showed a suprasellar mass. Histopathology of the mass showed the findings of palisading epithelium and wet keratin. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Craniopharyngiomas are slow-growing tumours arising from remnants of Rathke's pouch, most often located in the suprasellar region with or without intrasellar extension.
  • They show a bimodal age distribution: One peak in childhood (5-15 years) and another in adults over 65.
  • It typically presents with headaches, visual disturbances, or, in children, growth retardation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency.
  • Typically measuring 3-4 cm, they are often cystic, sometimes multiloculated, and may encroach on the optic chiasm or cranial nerves, with two histologic subtypes: adamantinomatous (common in children) and papillary (common in adults).
  • The adamantinomatous variant features nests or cords of squamous epithelium in a spongy reticulum, peripheral palisading, wet keratin as shown below, and frequent dystrophic calcification.
  • The cysts may be filled with cholesterol-rich fluid, linked to CTNNB1 mutations activating Wnt signalling.
  • The papillary variant consists of solid squamous epithelium without wet keratin, occasional calcifications, and is associated with BRAF V600E mutations, which have therapeutic implications.
  • Lesions under 5 cm generally have excellent recurrence-free survival, whereas larger tumours may be more invasive.
  • Malignant transformation into squamous carcinoma is rare and typically follows irradiation.

Explanation of other options:

Pituitary adenoma (Option B): Pituitary adenomas are typically soft, well-circumscribed tumours that may remain confined to the sella turcica or expand to erode surrounding bone and compress nearby structures, with larger lesions sometimes infiltrating adjacent tissues. Histologically, they consist of uniform polygonal cells arranged in sheets or cords with sparse supporting connective tissue, giving a soft, gelatinous consistency, and show low mitotic activity unless aggressive. Clinically, they cause symptoms through hormone hypersecretion or local mass effects, which may include visual field defects, signs of raised intracranial pressure, and hypopituitarism.

Rathke's cleft cyst (Option C): These cysts are lined by ciliated cuboidal epithelium, containing occasional goblet cells and anterior pituitary cells, and can accumulate protein-rich fluid, leading to expansion that compresses the normal gland. It can lead to hypopituitarism.

Meningioma (Option D): Meningiomas are typically rubbery, rounded dural masses that compress the brain and often contain psammomatous calcifications. Clinically, they are slow-growing, causing vague or focal neurological symptoms from brain compression, commonly arising in locations such as the parasagittal region, convexities, olfactory groove, and sella turcica. They are rare in children, more frequent in women, and may grow faster during pregnancy due to hormone receptor expression.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with fatigue, generalised lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. After examination and laboratory investigations, a diagnosis of CLL is made. Which of the following laboratory techniques is most useful to compare and quantify CD markers on cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, flow cytometry is most useful to compare and quantify CD markers in cells.

  • Flow cytometry is a rapid, laser-based quantitative technique for assessing multiple cell characteristics, requiring viable cells in suspension.
  • It is primarily used to detect cellular antigens from blood-derived (liquid) tumours, such as B-cell and T-cell lymphomas, leukaemias, and myeloid neoplasms and is commonly applied for immunophenotyping cell populations
  • Unlike immunohistochemistry, it allows simultaneous analysis of several antigens on individual cells using specific antibodies tagged with various fluorescent dyes, commonly employing monoclonal antibodies against various CD markers.
  • This allows identification of distinct cell populations such as CD4-positive and CD8-positive T cells, B cells, macrophages, and cytokine-expressing cells, with applications in both clinical diagnostics and biomedical research.

Explanation of other options:

ELISA (Option A): The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a widely used laboratory method for detecting and quantifying antibodies by linking an enzyme to an antibody and measuring the resulting enzyme activity with a substrate. Known antigens are bound to a solid surface, exposed to patient antibody samples, and then treated with enzyme-labelled anti-immunoglobulins. The resulting colour change upon substrate addition reflects the amount of antibody bound. This technique is applied to diagnose infectious diseases like HIV and syphilis, identify autoantibodies in autoimmune conditions such as lupus or scleroderma, and has variations including chemiluminescence and multiplex particle-based assays.

Western blot (Option B): Western blot, also known as immunoblot, is used to detect specific antigens within a complex protein mixture by first separating proteins via SDS-PAGE and transferring them to a membrane. The membrane is incubated with patient serum, and if antibodies are present, they bind to the corresponding proteins. These are then visualised using an enzyme-labelled secondary antibody and substrate, producing a detectable colour band. This method is commonly applied as a confirmatory test for infections such as HCV and Lyme disease.

Immunohistochemistry (Option D): Immunohistochemistry uses specific antibodies to identify cellular products or markers, aiding in the diagnosis and management of malignancies. It helps classify undifferentiated tumours, determine the site of origin in metastatic cases, and detect molecules with prognostic or therapeutic relevance, such as hormone receptors, ERBB2, and ALK proteins. These markers guide accurate tumour identification, prognosis assessment, and targeted treatment selection.

questions.text: Antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) positivity is most strongly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, anti-mitochondrial antibodies are most strongly associated with primary biliary cholangitis.

  • Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is an autoimmune disease marked by chronic inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts, sparing large intrahepatic and extrahepatic ducts.
  • It predominantly affects women (9:1 ratio), with peak incidence between ages 40-50.
  • The disease likely results from T lymphocyte-mediated injury to small interlobular bile ducts, possibly triggered by environmental factors in genetically susceptible individuals, leading to bile salt retention, hepatocellular injury, and eventual cirrhosis.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies against the E2 subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex are present in 90-95% of cases and are highly characteristic, though not directly linked to pathogenesis. Other autoantibodies may also occur.
  • Morphologically, PBC is defined by lymphocytic infiltration and epithelial injury of small bile ducts, often with poorly formed granulomas and the distinctive florid duct lesion as shown below, progressing to ductopenia and periportal changes such as feathery degeneration.
  • Clinically, patients may present with fatigue, pruritus, hypercholesterolemia, jaundice, xanthelasmas, steatorrhea, and vitamin D-related bone disease, with frequent association with other autoimmune conditions.
  • Diagnosis is supported by elevated alkaline phosphatase, presence of antimitochondrial antibodies, and characteristic histology.
  • The disease progresses slowly, but some develop end-stage liver disease over 15-20 years.
  • Oral ursodeoxycholic acid slows progression in most but not all patients.
  • In advanced cases, liver transplantation offers a better prognosis in terms of survival. PBC also carries an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option A): Type 1autoimmune hepatitis, which is more common, is typically marked by the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies. Additional antibodies may include those against soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas antigen (SLA/LPA) and, less commonly, anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA), which are more characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis. Type 2 is more frequently seen in children and is characterised by anti-liver kidney microsome-1 (LKM-1) antibodies directed against CYP2D6, as well as anti-liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies. In both types, serum IgG levels are often elevated, which can aid in diagnosis.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option C): Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal recessive protein-folding disorder characterised by markedly reduced circulating α1AT, leading to unopposed neutrophil elastase activity and resulting in pulmonary emphysema, as well as liver disease from hepatocellular accumulation of misfolded protein.

Wilson disease (Option D): Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by ATP7B gene mutations, leading to defective copper transport into bile and reduced incorporation into ceruloplasmin, resulting in toxic copper accumulation in organs such as the liver, brain, and eyes. Clinical manifestations vary and may include hepatic injury, neurologic symptoms, psychiatric disturbances, and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 1 month history of cough, chest pain, and dyspnea. Imaging reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of a mediastinal lymph node shows non caseating granulomas containing stellate inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical features of cough, dyspnea, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy along with biopsy revealing stellate inclusion bodies and non-caseating granulomas is sarcoidosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder that can affect multiple organs, most frequently the lungs, eyes, and skin, with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or parenchymal lung disease present in 90% of cases.
  • It often occurs in adults under 40, with higher prevalence in women, and is characterised pathologically by well-formed non-necrotising granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages and giant cells.
  • These sometimes contain stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies, as shown below. Another finding commonly seen is laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins called Schaumann bodies.
  • Immunologic abnormalities include a predominance of CD4+ T cells with elevated Th1 cytokines, increased local cytokine production, and impaired dendritic cell function, leading to granuloma formation.
  • The lungs are a frequent site of involvement, often showing granulomas along lymphatics near bronchi and blood vessels, with possible coalescence into small palpable nodules in advanced disease. Varying stages of fibrosis and hyalinization may be present.
  • Lymph node involvement is seen in almost all cases, especially in the hilar and mediastinal regions, with nodes appearing enlarged and discrete, sometimes calcified.
  • Skin lesions appear in a quarter of patients, ranging from discrete nodules to erythematous plaques or erythema nodosum.
  • Ocular involvement includes iritis or iridocyclitis, which may lead to glaucoma or vision loss, and is often associated with lacrimal gland inflammation and sicca syndrome.
  • Bilateral salivary gland involvement produces Mikulicz syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Histologically, tuberculosis is characterised by granulomatous inflammation forming predominantly caseating tubercles. These granulomas are composed of a fibroblastic rim with lymphocytes and often contain multinucleated giant cells. Progressive primary tuberculosis frequently mimics acute bacterial pneumonia, presenting with lobar consolidation, enlargement of hilar lymph nodes, and accumulation of pleural fluid.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Option C): Morphologically, granulomatosis with polyangiitis shows upper respiratory tract lesions ranging from sinusitis with mucosal granulomas to ulcerative lesions, often featuring geographic necrosis with vasculitis, necrotising granulomas in the lungs, and renal involvement from focal segmental necrotising glomerulonephritis to crescentic glomerulonephritis. Clinically, it often affects middle-aged men and presents with bilateral pneumonitis, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations, and renal disease, alongside systemic symptoms such as rash, myalgia, and fever.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): In hypersensitivity pneumonitis, histological features vary with disease stage. Acute lesions show alveolar damage shortly after antigen exposure, while subacute lesions are bronchiolocentric with interstitial pneumonitis composed of lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages, and non-necrotising granulomas.  Chronic cases reveal interstitial fibrosis, fibroblastic foci, honeycombing, and obliterative bronchiolitis. Clinically, acute episodes present with fever, dyspnea, cough, and leukocytosis within hours of exposure, recurring with re-exposure, whereas prolonged antigen contact can lead to chronic progressive fibrosis, dyspnea, and cyanosis, resembling other chronic interstitial lung diseases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with rapidly progressive swelling, pain, foul-smelling discharge, and discolouration of the hand following a traumatic injury, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image, along with history of pain, swelling, and foul-smelling discharge after trauma is suggestive of wet gangrene.

  • Gangrene is the death of visible tissue, turning black due to haemoglobin breakdown and iron sulphide formation, most often in the distal limbs from arterial obstruction such as thrombosis, embolus, or arteritis.
  • Dry gangrene occurs when tissue dries out from gradual blood flow reduction, typically from atheromatous artery narrowing, while wet gangrene arises when infection and putrefaction are superadded, producing crepitus from gas-forming organisms and requiring urgent surgery. (Option B ruled out)
  • Separation between dead and living tissue occurs via granulation tissue formation, progressing faster and more cleanly in dry gangrene if the blood supply is adequate, but is delayed when bone is involved.
  • In wet gangrene, infection and pus formation spread into the adjacent healthy tissue, resulting in the final demarcation line forming closer to the body than it does in dry gangrene.

Explanation of other options:

Infectious tenosynovitis (Option C): Infectious flexor tenosynovitis (FTS) is most often caused by bacterial pathogens such as Staphylococcus and Streptococcus, primarily following trauma. Clinically, it presents as an acute infection of the tendon sheath with pain, redness, and fever. On examination, Kanavel’s cardinal signs are seen, which include the finger resting in slight flexion, fusiform swelling, tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath, and pain on passive extension of the affected digit.

Raynaud phenomenon (Option D): Raynaud phenomenon presents with exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles, most often affecting the fingers and toes, and sometimes the nose, ears, or lips, producing red, white, and blue colour changes along the digits due to alternating vasodilation, vasoconstriction, and cyanosis. In the primary form, it is typically symmetrical, more common in young women, and usually benign, though chronic cases may cause skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle atrophy. Secondary Raynaud phenomenon is associated with underlying arterial diseases, tends to be asymmetrical, and progressively worsens over time.

choices.text: Destruction of exocrine glands by neutrophils
Lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands
Deposition of amyloid in salivary glands

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with dry eyes and dry mouth. Laboratory tests reveal positive anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies. What is the most likely underlying pathological mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of dry eyes and dry mouth, along with anti-Ro and anti-La positivity is suggestive of Sjogren’s syndrome, characterised by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands.

  • Sjogren syndrome is a chronic autoimmune disease characterised by immune-mediated destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands, leading to dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia).
  • It can occur as a primary form (sicca syndrome) or secondary to other autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, polymyositis, and scleroderma.
  • Pathogenesis involves lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the glands as shown below, with predominantly activated CD4+ T cells, plasma cells, and some B cells. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Rheumatoid factor is present in most cases and is also associated with ANA positivity..
  • Antibodies against SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detectable in up to 90% of patients and are important serologic markers.
  • Morphologically, major targets are the lacrimal and salivary glands, but other exocrine glands (respiratory, gastrointestinal, vaginal) may be affected.
  • Early changes show periductal and perivascular lymphoid infiltration. Later, there is ductal epithelial hyperplasia, acinar atrophy, fibrosis, hyalinization, and fat replacement, with possible lymphoid follicles and germinal centres.
  • Clinically, it occurs most often in women aged 50-60 years, with keratoconjunctivitis causing burning, itching, and blurred vision. Xerostomia causes difficulty swallowing solid foods, decreased taste, oral dryness, fissuring, and parotid enlargement in half of patients.
  • The combination of lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement was once termed Mikulicz disease, now referred to as Mikulicz syndrome, which may result from various causes, including sarcoidosis, IgG4-related disease, lymphoma, or other tumours.
  • Chronic lymphocytic inflammation carries a risk of developing marginal zone lymphoma.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient with gluten sensitivity presents with intensely itchy, grouped vesicular lesions on the extensor surfaces. A skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given features of pruritic vesicular lesions on extensor surfaces in a patient with gluten sensitivity and direct immunofluorescence showing deposits on the tips of dermal papillae is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis.

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is a rare, chronic, intensely pruritic disorder characterised by urticaria-like papules, grouped vesicles, or urticarial plaques that are symmetrically distributed, most often on extensor surfaces such as the elbows, knees, buttocks, and back with occasional excoriations and crusted papules due to scratching.
  • The disease affects predominantly men, typically presenting in the third to fourth decades, though it can occur at any age, including childhood, and has a chronic course.
  • Pruritus may have a burning or stinging quality, with lesions appearing 12-24 hours after symptom onset.
  • Almost all patients have associated, usually subclinical, gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease, and over 90% express the HLA-B8/DRw3 and HLA-DQw2 haplotypes.
  • Pathogenesis involves genetically predisposed individuals developing IgA antibodies against dietary gluten (gliadin) that cross-react with reticulin in the anchoring fibrils between the epidermal basement membrane and superficial dermis, producing injury, inflammation, and subepidermal blisters.
  • Biopsy of early lesions reveals neutrophil-rich infiltrates with fibrin, oedema, and microvesicles at the tips of dermal papilla.
  • Direct immunofluorescence of normal-appearing perilesional skin shows discontinuous, granular IgA deposits (with or without complement) localised to dermal papillae and along the basement membrane zone.
  • These deposits remain unaffected by medication but diminish or disappear after long-term adherence to a strict gluten-free diet. This finding distinguishes the disease from linear IgA deposition disorders.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement in celiac disease, when present, includes blunting of intestinal villi and lymphocytic infiltration of the lamina propria, reversible with a gluten-free diet. Gluten exposure can trigger both cutaneous and intestinal flares.
  • The condition is associated with IgA anti-endomysial autoantibodies targeting tissue transglutaminase. There is also an increased incidence of autoimmune conditions such as thyroid abnormalities, achlorhydria, atrophic gastritis, and autoantibodies to gastric parietal cells, likely linked to the high prevalence of HLA-B8/DRw3 in affected patients.
  • Treatment relies on dapsone, a sulfone, which provides rapid (24-48 hours) relief but requires pretreatment screening (e.g., for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency) and ongoing monitoring to avoid complications such as hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially at doses above 100 mg/day.
  • Gluten restriction is essential, often reducing dapsone needs and preventing relapses.

Explanation of other options:

Bullous pemphigoid (Option A): Bullous pemphigoid primarily affects the elderly, presenting with tense, clear-fluid-filled bullae on erythematous or normal skin, often involving thighs, flexor forearms, axillae, groin, and lower abdomen, with oral lesions in some cases. Morphologically, the bullae are subepidermal and nonacantholytic, with eosinophil-rich inflammatory infiltrates beneath the epidermal basal layer. Direct immunofluorescence typically shows continuous linear antibody deposition at the dermoepidermal junction, as shown below, reflecting antibodies against BPAG antigens that disrupt epidermal attachment.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B): Pemphigus vulgaris, the most common pemphigus variant, affects mucosa and skin, often beginning with persistent oral ulcers before skin involvement. Lesions are superficial vesicles and bullae that rupture easily, leaving shallow erosions with crust. Histology shows acantholysis with suprabasal blister formation where basal cells form a row of tombstones, accompanied by dermal lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. On direct immunofluorescence, there is intercellular IgG deposition throughout the epidermis in a fish-net pattern, as shown below.

Psoriasis (Option D): Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis with a probable autoimmune basis, commonly affecting extensor surfaces like the elbows, knees, and scalp, \may be associated with arthritis, nail changes, or systemic conditions. Lesions are typically well-demarcated, pink to salmon-colored plaques with loosely adherent silvery-white scales, and histology shows marked acanthosis with elongation of rete ridges, as shown below, thinning or absence of the stratum granulosum, and extensive parakeratosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a persistent red lesion on the lateral border of the tongue. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following viral infections is most strongly associated with this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity is associated with human papillomavirus.

  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) constitutes up to 80% of SCCs in this region, most commonly involving the tonsils, base of tongue, and pharynx, and is frequently associated with oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV-16.
  • The incidence of HPV-associated SCC of the oropharynx has more than doubled in recent decades, and these tumours often arise in the reticulated epithelium of the tonsillar crypts, presenting as nonkeratinizing, basaloid cell proliferations in nests and cords accompanied by sheets of lymphocytes, as shown below.
  • Clinically, HPV-associated SCCs may lack obvious mucosal lesions but are notable for significant cervical lymphadenopathy, and p16 protein overexpression is a useful marker for diagnosis, with PCR or in situ hybridization serving as confirmatory tests.
  • In contrast, keratinizing SCCs, more often linked to smoking and alcohol, usually originate as dysplastic lesions that may progress to full-thickness dysplasia (carcinoma in situ) before invading the underlying stroma.
  • They can vary from well-differentiated to anaplastic forms, and histologic differentiation does not correlate with behaviour. These tumours tend to infiltrate locally before metastasising, with cervical lymph nodes as common sites for local spread, and lungs, liver, and bones as frequent sites for distant metastases.
  • Long-term outcomes are generally better in HPV-positive cases.
  • A significant concern in SCC of the oropharynx is field cancerization, where patients, particularly those with classic SCC, face a high risk of developing new primary tumours due to widespread mucosal carcinogen exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Epstein–Barr virus (Option A): Hairy leukoplakia is an EBV-associated oral lesion typically seen on the lateral border of the tongue in immunocompromised individuals, notably those with HIV, but also in cases of cancer therapy, transplant-related immunosuppression, and advanced age. It appears as white, confluent,  hyperkeratotic patches that cannot be scraped off, with histology showing hyperparakeratosis, acanthosis with balloon cells, and detectable EBV RNA and proteins in lesional cells. Malignancies associated with EBV include nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and other B-cell lymphomas.

Cytomegalovirus (Option B): In immunocompetent individuals beyond the neonatal stage, CMV infection most often presents as an infectious mononucleosis syndrome, characterised by fever, atypical lymphocytosis, lymph node enlargement, and hepatitis with hepatomegaly and abnormal liver function test results.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Oral herpes, most often due to HSV-1, commonly presents in children as acute gingivostomatitis and in adults as acute pharyngitis, with vesicles and ulcerations that may be accompanied by fever, lymphadenopathy, and anorexia. Lesions range from small vesicles to large bullae containing clear fluid, which rupture to form painful shallow ulcers. Histology shows intracellular and intercellular oedema with intranuclear viral inclusions or multinucleated giant cells, demonstrable by the Tzanck test.
